classifications.note: Center of mass: $\vec{r}_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_i\vec{r}_i}{\sum m_i}$, components: $x_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_ix_i}{\sum m_i}$, $y_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_iy_i}{\sum m_i}$, $z_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_iz_i}{\sum m_i}$, for symmetric objects: CM lies on symmetry elements

principles.statement: Center of mass provides a unified description of system motion: Definition: $\vec{r}_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\sum m_i\vec{r}_i$; Weighted average of positions; Mass-weighted mean position; Vector quantity. Physical Significance: Point where mass balances; Point that follows smooth trajectory; Reference for rotational motion; Where external forces effectively act. Discrete Systems: For N particles: $x_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_ix_i}{\sum m_i}$; $y_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_iy_i}{\sum m_i}$; $z_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_iz_i}{\sum m_i}$; Component-wise calculation. Two-Particle System: Special case: $\vec{r}_{CM} = \frac{m_1\vec{r}_1 + m_2\vec{r}_2}{m_1 + m_2}$; Lies on line connecting particles; Closer to more massive particle; Divides distance in inverse mass ratio. Symmetry Principles: Object with symmetry plane: CM lies in that plane; Object with symmetry axis: CM lies on that axis; Object with symmetry point: CM at that point; Multiple symmetries constrain CM position. Total Mass: M = Σm_i; Sum of all individual masses; Used as normalization factor; Important for motion equations. Vector Nature: Position vector from origin; Components in coordinate system; Independent of coordinate choice (physical point); Transforms properly between frames. Applications: Balance point finding; Motion analysis; Collision studies; Astronomical systems; Engineering design.
principles.application: Calculate center of mass for discrete particle systems. Determine CM for two-particle systems. Apply symmetry principles to find CM. Compute CM coordinates component-wise. Understand physical significance of CM. Apply to simple system analysis.
principles.example: Find CM of particle arrays. Locate balance points. Analyze simple molecule geometry. Calculate CM for basic structures.
principles.analogy: Like the geographic center of population - it's not necessarily where most people live, but the average location weighted by population density, and this point can have very smooth movement even when individuals move erratically, similar to how center of mass moves smoothly while particles may have complex motions

worked_examples.title: Three-Particle System
worked_examples.problem: Three masses are arranged: 2 kg at (0,0), 3 kg at (4,0), 1 kg at (0,3). Find the center of mass coordinates.

step_by_step.explanation: CM is closer to the 3 kg mass at (4,0) since it's heaviest; Not at geometric center due to unequal masses
System would balance at (2,0.5) if supported there

worked_examples.final_answer: Center of mass = (2.0 m, 0.5 m); Weighted average position reflects mass distribution

worked_examples.title: Linear Mass Array
worked_examples.problem: Masses of 1 kg, 4 kg, and 2 kg are placed at x = 0 m, 2 m, and 5 m on the x-axis. Find the center of mass.

step_by_step.explanation: Since all masses on x-axis, CM is at (2.571, 0, 0)
Heaviest mass (4 kg) at x=2 pulls CM toward it; Light mass (1 kg) at origin has little effect
CM is 0.571 m from the 4 kg mass (at 2 m) and 2.429 m from the 1 kg mass (at 0 m); Ratio ≈ 1:4.25, roughly inverse mass ratio
If supported at x=2.571 m, system would balance
CM lies between the 4 kg and 2 kg masses, closer to the heavier 4 kg mass

worked_examples.final_answer: Center of mass at x = 2.57 m; One-dimensional calculation demonstrates mass weighting

classifications.note: Continuous CM: $x_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\int x dm$, $y_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\int y dm$, $z_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\int z dm$, for uniform density: dm = ρdV, symmetric objects: CM at geometric center, composite objects: treat as discrete system of components

principles.statement: Continuous objects extend CM concepts to distributed mass: Integration Formulation: $x_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\int x dm$; $y_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\int y dm$; $z_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\int z dm$; Mass element dm depends on geometry. Uniform Density: dm = ρdV (volume), ρdA (area), or ρdl (length); Constant ρ cancels in ratios; CM depends only on geometry. Common Shapes: Rod: CM at midpoint; Rectangular plate: CM at intersection of diagonals; Solid sphere: CM at center; Circular disk: CM at center. Symmetry Principles: Spherical symmetry: CM at center; Cylindrical symmetry: CM on axis; Planar symmetry: CM in plane; Multiple symmetries fully determine CM position. Composite Objects: Treat as collection of simple shapes; Use discrete CM formula with component masses and CMs; Can handle holes using negative mass. Density Variations: Non-uniform density: ρ = ρ(x,y,z); Must include density in integrals; CM shifts toward higher density regions; More complex calculations. Choice of Coordinates: Strategic coordinate placement simplifies integrals; Often place origin at symmetry point; Use symmetry to reduce dimensions; Choose coordinate axes along symmetry directions. Practical Applications: Vehicle design for stability; Aircraft balance; Structural engineering; Sports equipment design; Astronomical bodies.

worked_examples.title: Uniform Rod Center of Mass
worked_examples.problem: Find the center of mass of a uniform thin rod of length L and mass M.

step_by_step.explanation: Place rod along x-axis from x=0 to x=L; Uniform linear density λ = M/L
x_CM = (1/M) ∫ x dm = (1/M) ∫₀ᴸ x (M/L) dx = (1/L) ∫₀ᴸ x dx
Since rod is thin and straight, y_CM = 0, z_CM = 0
Rod symmetric about midpoint; CM should be at center ✓
Uniform rod balances at its center regardless of orientation

worked_examples.final_answer: Center of mass at midpoint: x = L/2; Uniform rod CM at geometric center

image.caption: Center of mass calculation for uniform rod

worked_examples.title: Composite Object - L-Shaped Plate
worked_examples.problem: An L-shaped plate consists of two rectangles: 2m×1m (mass 4 kg) and 1m×1m (mass 2 kg) joined. Find center of mass relative to corner where they meet.

step_by_step.explanation: Place origin at corner where rectangles meet; x horizontal, y vertical
Mass m₁ = 4 kg; CM at (0.5, 1.0) - width 1m so x=0.5, height 2m so y=1.0
Mass m₂ = 2 kg; CM at (1.5, 0.5) - extends from x=1 to x=2 so x=1.5, height 1m so y=0.5
CM lies inside the L-shape; Closer to heavier vertical rectangle
Object would balance if supported at (0.833, 0.833)

worked_examples.final_answer: Center of mass = (0.833 m, 0.833 m); Composite object treated as discrete system of components

classifications.note: CM velocity: $\vec{v}_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_i\vec{v}_i}{\sum m_i}$, CM acceleration: $\vec{a}_{CM} = \frac{\sum m_i\vec{a}_i}{\sum m_i} = \frac{\vec{F}_{ext}}{M}$, in isolated system: $\vec{v}_{CM}$ constant, in explosions: CM continues original trajectory

principles.principle: Center of Mass Motion and Applications
principles.statement: Center of mass motion follows elegant physical laws: CM Velocity: $\vec{v}_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\sum m_i\vec{v}_i$; Mass-weighted average velocity; Related to total momentum: $\vec{p}_{total} = M\vec{v}_{CM}$. CM Acceleration: $\vec{a}_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\sum m_i\vec{a}_i = \frac{\vec{F}_{net,ext}}{M}$; Determined only by external forces; Internal forces cancel in pairs. Motion Theorem: CM moves as if all mass concentrated there and all external forces applied there; Powerful simplification of complex systems. Isolated Systems: If $\vec{F}_{net,ext} = 0$, then $\vec{v}_{CM}$ constant; CM moves with constant velocity; Internal motions don't affect CM trajectory. Collision Applications: In any collision (isolated system), CM velocity unchanged; Useful reference frame for analysis; CM frame often simplifies mathematics. Explosion Scenarios: Fragments fly in all directions; CM continues original trajectory; Vector sum of fragment momenta = 0 in CM frame; Conservation of CM motion. Rocket Motion: Variable mass system; CM still follows $\vec{F}_{ext} = M\vec{a}_{CM}$; Thrust is internal force; Gravity external. Real-World Examples: Sports: athlete's CM trajectory; Vehicles: stability analysis; Astronomy: multi-body systems; Engineering: balance and vibration.

worked_examples.title: Explosion Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A 6 kg projectile moving 40 m/s east explodes into three pieces: 2 kg at 60 m/s north, 1 kg at 80 m/s west, and 3 kg piece. Find the third piece's velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: v_CM = 40 m/s east (entire mass moves together before explosion)
In isolated system (no external forces), v_CM unchanged = 40 m/s east
Total momentum before = total momentum after; (6)(40 east) = (2)(60 north) + (1)(80 west) + (3)(v₃)

worked_examples.final_answer: Third piece velocity = 113.9 m/s at 20.6° south of east; CM continues original trajectory despite explosion

image.caption: Center of mass analysis of explosion scenario

worked_examples.title: Collision in CM Frame
worked_examples.problem: Two cars collide: 1200 kg at 20 m/s east, 800 kg at 15 m/s west. Find: (a) CM velocity, (b) velocities in CM frame, (c) if perfectly inelastic, final velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: u₁ = v₁ - v_CM = 20 - 6 = 14 m/s east; u₂ = v₂ - v_CM = -15 - 6 = -21 m/s east (21 m/s west)

step_by_step.step: Verify zero momentum in CM frame

step_by_step.explanation: Objects stick together; In CM frame, final velocity = 0 (they stop relative to CM)

worked_examples.final_answer: CM velocity = 6 m/s east; CM frame velocities: 14 m/s east and 21 m/s west; Perfectly inelastic final velocity = 6 m/s east; CM frame provides insight into collision

image.caption: Collision analysis using center of mass frame

common_misconceptions: Thinking CM is always where most mass is located
Believing CM must be within the physical object
Confusing geometric center with center of mass
Thinking internal forces affect CM motion
Believing CM is only for theoretical calculations
Confusing CM with center of gravity in non-uniform fields
Thinking CM motion is always simple harmonic
summary: The center of mass represents the average position of mass distribution in a system, following simple motion determined by net external forces while internal forces cancel out. For discrete systems, CM is calculated as a mass-weighted average of positions, while continuous objects require integration. Symmetric objects often have CM at obvious geometric centers. The CM motion theorem states that the center of mass moves as if all mass were concentrated there and all external forces applied there, providing powerful simplifications for analyzing collisions, explosions, rocket motion, and complex multi-body systems. These concepts find applications across physics, engineering, sports science, and many other fields where system dynamics must be understood and optimized.
